About

Sometimes, programming is about looking at code that hurts and making it so beautiful you want to tell the world about it. To me, this is was certainly one of those times.

For some months, I've been working on a small game / game engine in Clojure. The main goal is to develop an architecture that can allow programming simple games in a functional, yet practical, style. But this is a story for another time.

The Jump State Machine: Na√Øve Implementation

What we'll be talking about today has to do with the implementation of the classical behaviour of jumping in platformers: "Press A to jump. Press and hold A to jump higher". When implementing this, I always like to think about it in terms of a state machine:

A naive implementation of the above state machine diagram will yield to something similar to this clojure code:

Most of the variable names are self explanatory. This convoluted code block is the result of multiple iterations of patching the original cond statement, which I haven't been able to recover. It may look bad but we all write code like this. It's the bare minimum that needs to be done in order for the thing to work in a reasonable way. I feel writing code like this is ok… As long as you go back and fix it at some point, that is!

It's Refactor Time!

So today, I decided it was time for a refactor. The first thing that I noticed is that in the cond clauses I was doing two things (sometimes implicitly):

  • Checking for the current state, such as :jumping or :on-air.
  • Checking for an additional condition, such as grounded or (< new-jump-time max-jump-time).

This, in fact, is because of the underlying concept of a state machine that lies whithin that mess of a code. In fact, the state machine shape of the logic arises when making all conditions explicit:

  • If the current state is :ready:
    • If the jump key is pressed, we change into :jumping.
    • If we are grounded, we stay in :ready.
    • Otherwise we are :on-air.
  • If the current state is :on-air:
    • If we are grounded, go back to :ready
    • Otherwise we stay :on-air

  • If the current state is :jumping:

    • If the jump key is pressed, and we can keep jumping, stay in :jumping:
    • If we can't keep jumping because the max time is exceeded or the jump key has been released, go to :on-air.

    -Otherwise we stay on :jumping

Those are the inner semantics of a state machine. It would be really nice if we had a language construct to directly specify those, but sadly we'll have to do it by carefully translating the nested if statements because it would be very difficult to… But wait! This is clojure, we have macros!

The State-Machine Macro.

The first step I like to do when writing a macro is defining its syntax by the means of an example. In this case, the chosen syntax was:

The state-machine macro takes a symbol and a list of triples <initial_state, condition, final_state>, which basically encode the arcs of the state machine. The little arrows are there because I like how they look.

Macro Input Validation With clojure.spec

One would thing validating the input of such a macro would be a difficult task only fit for the bravest and truest clojurists, but with the recent addition of clojure.spec validating macro input is not scary anymore!

In this case, a spec that syntactically validates the input of our macro would be the following:

With this, we get the parsing and destructuring of the macro body for free. Conforming the macro body against this spec would yield the following structure:

As you can see, much of the work has already been laid out for us. Despite that, this lacks all semantical checks. Error cases such as like non-existing states or non-exhaustive patterns should be checked separately.

With the body-parser spec, we are ready to write our macro. The implementation is split in two parts. The state-machine macro, which creates a case statement for each of the initial states and the state-cond helper macro, which creates, for each of the case clauses, a cond statement branching on the several conditions.

There are also some minor points in the implementation I feel are worth mentioning:

  • The maybe-conform function is pure goodness. I find myself using it a lot. It takes the same arguments as conform plus an error messsage. If the spec is invalid throws with the error message plus the spec/explain-str string.
  • The {:style/indent 1} metadata in the main macro helps cider (and presumably most other clojure IDE-like tools)perform the correct indentation of the macro.
  • Whenever you want to generate multiple forms such as in a cond statement, with all elements at the same level, I find this combination of unquote splicing ~@ and mapcat to be quite useful.

Wrapping Up

With this macro I made my code more beautiful and readable
